API Documentation

User Routes:

Endpoints for user-related operations.

Endpoint Description Request Method Protected Response
/users/login User Login POST No Returns an access token upon successful login and also the user details. (res.data.token, res.data.user)
/users/signup User Signup POST No Returns an access token upon successful signup and also the user details. (res.data.token, res.data.user)

Consumer Routes:

Endpoints for consumer-related operations.

Endpoint Description Request Method Protected Response
/consumer Create an Order POST Yes Returns the created order details. (res.data.order)
/consumer/{orderID} Get an Order GET Yes Returns the order details. (res.data.order)

Shipper Routes:

Endpoints for shipper-related operations.

Endpoint Description Request Method Protected Response
/shipper Get All Orders GET Yes Returns a list of orders. (res.data.orders)
/shipper/accept/{orderID} Accept Delivery GET Yes Returns a success message upon successful acceptance.
/shipper/pickUp/{orderID} Confirm Pick-up GET Yes Returns a success message upon successful confirmation.
/shipper/otw/{orderID} Confirm On the Way GET Yes Returns a success message upon successful confirmation.
/shipper/otp/{orderID} Send OTP GET Yes Returns a success message upon successful OTP generation.
/shipper/otp/{orderID} Verify OTP POST Yes Returns a success message upon successful OTP verification.

THINGS TO NOTE

- Ensure to include the Authorization header with a valid token as "Bearer {token}" for authentication and authorization to access the protected routes.

- On successful request, the response will have the field "status" set to success i.e res.data.status = success.

- The following response status codes (can be accessed using res.status) and the corresponding meanings -

  • 200 OK: The request was successful, and the response body contains the requested data.
  • 201 Created: The request was successful, and a new resource was created as a result
  • 204 No Content: The deletion requested for the data was successful.
  • 400 Bad Request: The request could not be understood or processed due to invalid syntax, missing parameters or validation errors.
  • 401 Unauthorized: The request requires authentication, and the token provided were either missing, invalid, or not in the correct format.
  • 404 Not Found: The requested resource could not be found on the server.
  • 500 Internal Server Error: An unexpected error occurred on the server while processing the request.
